attributes.title: The lived experiences of the third generation of holocaust survivors: a systematic literature review

summary.value:
This project is a systematic review of the literature that aims to aims to recognise, describe and analyse the patterns of information regarding the lived experiences of
grandchildren of holocaust survivors as they emerged from the selected studies. 
Experience is a key subject that qualitative research aims to address and understand in the context of the concrete and meaningful world of the human being. An individual's lived experience may include their wishes, desires, feelings, motivations and belief systems. These aspects may manifest themselves in the individual's behaviours and actions which in turn may impact their physical, mental health and wellbeing.
Inclusion: We will include qualitative and mixed methods studies (however, only qualitative data will be extracted) which may be population or community based, cross-sectional and cohort studies. Studies of a theoretical or conceptual nature. Studies must be published in a peer-reviewed journal.
Exclusion: We will exclude studies using only quantitative methods and studies with no direct information on the target population.
After removal of duplicates, one reviewer will independently screen retrieved titles and abstracts, with a second reviewer blindly screening the first 10% of the entries and a third reviewer the last 10% of the entries. Through collaboration, a census will be reached between the three reviewers while applying the inclusion criteria. The same strategy will be utilised in the full-text screening of articles. Extracted data from articles will include; Settings, population and participant demographics, methodology, outcomes of measurements and key qualitative findings. Missing data will be requested from study authors. The Walsh and Downe (2006) critical appraisal tool and checklist will be used to assess the quality of extracted papers.
A thematic synthesis will be employed to analyse the data from qualitative studies to recognise and describe patterns of information across the included studies.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Concerns about downward socioeconomic mobility and avoidance goals

other.value: We will also conduct exploratory analyses of our data as follows. We will conduct the primary analyses mentioned above including regulatory focus as a covariate after we conduct the analyses without including regulatory focus as a covariate. We will also explore student performance on an anagram task(s) as an indicator of persistence and mastery-avoidance.

sample.value: We will aim to recruit 500 participants. A power analysis using the G*Power computer program indicated that a total sample of 432 people would be needed to detect small-medium effects (Effect size f =.15) with 80% power. Sampling 500 students gives us flexibility to still reach desired power if students are unable to complete the study or we need to exclude any data.

analyses.value:
We will conduct a 3 (condition: downward mobility vs. active comparison vs. control) X 2 (race-ethnicity: White vs. non-White) ANOVA to examine the effects of condition, race-ethnicity, and their interaction on participants’ adoption of mastery-avoidance goals. We will examine if there is a main effect of condition and a main effect of race-ethnicity. Additionally, we will examine if there is a significant condition by race-ethnicity interaction. Specifically, we will examine if among non-White college students, those randomly assigned to the downward mobility condition displayed significantly greater adoption of mastery-avoidance goals than those randomly assigned to the control condition and those assigned to the upward mobility active comparison condition.
We will conduct a 3 (condition: downward mobility vs. active comparison vs. control) X 2 (race-ethnicity: White vs. non-White) ANOVA to examine the effects of condition, race-ethnicity, and their interaction on participants’ adoption of performance-avoidance goals. We will examine if there is a main effect of condition and a main effect of race-ethnicity. Additionally, we will examine if there is a significant condition by race-ethnicity interaction. Specifically, we will examine if among non-White college students, those randomly assigned to the downward mobility condition displayed significantly greater adoption of performance-avoidance goals than those randomly assigned to the control condition and those assigned to the upward mobility active comparison condition.

outliers.value: There will be one attention check asking all participants to respond to the following item, “This item is here to screen out random responding; please give a three as a response to this item.” Participants who are randomly assigned to either the downward mobility condition or the active comparison condition will also be exposed to two additional attention checks. These items will ask questions related to the manipulation. Specifically, one item will ask, “How many Americans (in the millions) are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility?” The correct response is 83 million. The second item will state “Americans are experiencing [upward/downward] socioeconomic mobility. Is this true or false?” The correct answer is true. We will exclude participants who failed these attention checks. However, we will conduct analysis of the data including those individuals who fail these attention checks before we conduct analysis of the data after excluding them.

dependent.value:
1)	Mastery-avoidance goals
a.	3-item scale: 1 (strongly disagree) – 5 (strongly agree)
i.	“My aim is to avoid learning less than I possibly could.” 
ii.	“I am striving to avoid an incomplete understanding of my course material.”
iii.	“My goal is to avoid learning less than it is possible to learn.”

2)	Performance-avoidance goals
a.	3-item scale: 1 (strongly disagree) – 5 (strongly agree)
i.	“My aim is to avoid doing worse than other students.” 
ii.	“I am striving to avoid performing worse than others.”
iii.	“My goal is to avoid performing poorly compared to others.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions. Participants’ beliefs about socioeconomic mobility will be manipulated using a brief report and accompanying figure describing current socioeconomic mobility trends in the United States. In the downward mobility condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience downward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying downward mobility trends from a higher position on the SES ladder to a lower position. In an active comparison condition, participants will read a report indicating that “An estimated over 83 million Americans, across all backgrounds, experience upward socioeconomic mobility in the United States.” The accompanying figure will depict arrows displaying upward mobility trends from a lower position on the SES ladder to a higher position. Participants in a passive control condition will not be exposed to any information about socioeconomic mobility.

hypothesis.value: We predict that students experimentally led to hold concerns about experiencing downward socioeconomic mobility will display greater (a) performance-avoidance goals and (b) mastery-avoidance goals, compared with students in control conditions. Further, (c) we also expect the relationship between concern about downward mobility and mastery-avoidance goals to be more pronounced among students from non-White racial-ethnic groups.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: RT and accuracy data between condition can be analyzed with paired t-test and repeated measured ANOVA. Accuracy analyses would be performed on arcsine transformed data.

sample.value:
Let’s power this for a test of the difference between the final, targeting saccade and other saccades. From the previous experiment, final saccades avg 141 pixels (SD 19). Other saccades avg 185 (SD 33). These values are correlated at about 0.3 across Os. Using G*Power, for an alpha of 0.05 and a power of 0.95, and this effect size of 1.36, we require 8 observers (actual power = 0.96). 

Working the other direction, 12 Os would allow us to see a 30 pixel difference in saccade length (assuming similar variance) with a power of 0.91.

We will test 12 observers.

analyses.value: The analyses will be conducted in MATLAB. Similar to the previous studies, we will use the results to test the size of UFOVs. The distribution of all fixations that do NOT land on the target is used to define the Explore UFOV. The distribution of the first saccades that land on a target defines the select UFOV because the target must have been selected during the previous fixation. We have found that the saccade after that first fixation on the target and before the target is ‘clicked’ are small, presumably corrective saccades. The size of the UFOVs can be calculated as the mean, mode, or median of the saccade distribution. These measures can be compared using standard t-test and ANOVA methods. Shapes of the distributions can be test with K-S statistics.

outliers.value: Observers can be excluded and replaced if their eye tracking data is defective (tracking ratio lower than 70%) or if their miss error rate exceeds 20%.

dependent.value: From the eye tracking data, the important variables are the length of saccades and the duration of the fixation (dwell time) between saccades. Reaction time and accuracy measures are of secondary interest here but are also recorded.

conditions.value:
The stimuli display always consists of 80 items. The position of the items is randomly selected. However, those positions remain fixed for an entire block of 800 trials. There are 4 blocks in total which are presented in a random order. In each block, there are 80% target present and 20% target absent trials. On a target absent trial, there are 26 large items (Ls) and 54 small items (consonants). On target present trials, either an L is replaced by a T or a consonant is replaced by a vowel. An observer ‘clicks’ on the target to collect it (or they press the space bar to move to the next trial when no target is found). After response, a new target (if target present) and all distractors are randomly positioned and rotated . From the observers point of view, a block is one, continuous search.

Observers are asked to collect 100 targets to complete the task, thus, without errors a block would consist of 100 target present and 25 target absent trials. The four blocks of the experiment consists of at least 500 trials.

hypothesis.value:
The main purpose of this study is to establish a clearer understanding about the relation between the Useful Field of View (UFOV) and visual search performance. The aim of the current study is to find out whether the size of the UFOV is sensitive to the search task observers have to perform. That is, whether UFOV would be different when Os search for different target on the same search display. Traditionally, the UFOV has also been treated as if it were a single entity of fixed size. Clearly, that is naïve since the UFOV must depend on what is being looked for and on the nature of the background. However, this has not been systematically studied. Another aim of this study is to see if more than one UFOV can operates during a single search task. This question arises in two forms that are easier to explain if we explain the actual task. The visual display consists of BIG L distractors and the occasional BIG T target intermixed with SMALL Consonant distractors among SMALL Vowel targets (A E I O U) . Observers can be instructed to search for T or Vowel or both. We hypothesize that the UFOV, revealed by eye movements, will differ across the three tasks.

Another question that would be interesting to examine in this experiment is whether observers are able to efficiently switch between search templates. In the one-target blocks, observers should have a clear template in their mind about the item they have to search for. However, this might be not the case in the mixed-target condition. By comparing the fixation duration on the distractors “belonging” to the opposite search category (i.e., on small distractor letters when searching for the T and on Ls when searching for the vowel) between one-target and mixed-target blocks we will be able to determine if observers can switch easily between templates within a display. For instance, if the fixation duration on small distractor letters is shorter in the one-target blocks when searching for the T as compared to the mixed-target blocks, we can say that the template vowel is disrupting the search for the T in the mixed-target blocks. Thus, the two templates might be in competition with each other. If the fixation duration on distractors belonging to the opposite search category was the same in the one-target and mixed-target block, observers might be able to switch between the vowel and the T template efficiently without costs.

Within a given task, there are three types of UFOV that can be measured. One UFOV defines where the eyes will move next. Where will I explore with my next fixation? This UFOV is defined by the size of saccades that do not land on a target. A related UFOV is based on what objects selected once the eyes have fixated on one location. This UFOV is defined by the distribution of final saccades that land on a target. We assume that you would not usually move the eyes to a target if you had not covertly selected and identified that target peripherally first. The third UFOV, not directly relevant here, is defined by the eccentricity function for these stimuli. That is, if attention is cued to a location, can you identify a target at that location? For the present task, we hypothesize that the exploration UFOV will have about 2X the radius of the selection UFOV, because the eyes will move beyond the selection UFOV to explore new items if no target was found.

summary.value:
Attaching a word doc with the preregistered analysis plan. It is also copied below.
This analysis plan was authored by Beth Morling, Grace Handley, and Anton Lebed
Published on Feb 3, 2020

SGHW Study Preregistered Data Analysis Plan

Data structure:
	3 levels, nested
		Level 1: Cohort (4 levels; F18_905, F18_1010, F19_905, F19_1010, )
		Level 2: Participant
Level 3: Exam 1, 2, 3, 4: Two exams for each person are in SGHW condition and two exams are TAU)

Cohort and Participant will be estimated as random intercepts but not random slopes
We have no strong a priori hypothesis about the covariance structure

Argument for combining year and section at the same level (Level 1): even though 9ams are the weaker sections, the weakness is accounted for by GPA--the only dependency we want to account for is the fact that they were hanging out in the same group, 
This leads us to a 3-level model, with Level I being “year/section cohort.” 

Long-form data file name: LongSGHWdata.sav (.csv)
Wide-form data file name: WideSGHWdata.sav (.csv)


Variables and Decisions
Dependent variables:
MC score for each exam, stated as pct	
Essay score for each exam, stated as pct
Metacognition score for each exam (Computed as absolute value of % estimated total score minus % actual total score); therefore positive score means more error in the estimate of performance
Satisfaction ratings from colored sheet (colored sheet is the post-exam survey we gave each student after each exam). 
DVs to be used for descriptives only:
Open-ended comments from colored sheet (post-exam questionnaire)
Other questions from the colored sheet (post-exam questionnaire)
Non-absolute value of metacognitive difference (estimated minus actual, such that positive scores mean overestimates and negative scores mean underestimates)
Moderators: 
	Exam order--effect predicted to be a bit stronger on first exam (hypotheses listed later)
GPA, recorded before Fall semester, used as a continuous moderator
Exclusions:
	Non-consenting students
	Any student who has a final course grade of W, L, F, or Z.
	Any student who missed an exam has missing data for that not zero.
Outliers:
	No plan to exclude outliers. 
Pre-analysis steps
Run an empty model to look at ICCs, report. 
(SPSS syntax presented at the end of this doc)


Full Statistical Model
(SPSS syntax presented at the end of this doc)
DVs: MC score (%), essay score (%), metacognition (abs value of %dif), Satisfaction ratings.

Comparisons: (Level 3)
Main effect of condition (2 levels)
Main effect of exam order (4 levels)
Main effect of pre-semester GPA (continuous)
Condition x exam order
Condition x GPA
Exam x GPA
Condition x exam x GPA

Syntax:



Predictions for MC, short answer, and metacognition DVs:
Main effect of pre-semester GPA
We expect a strong association (strongest of the study) between pre-semester GPA and MC exam scores
We expect a strong association (strongest of the study) between pre-semester GPA and essay exam scores 
We expect a moderate association between pre-semester GPA and Absolute metacognition (Higher GPA associated with lower absolute value difference)

B. Condition main effects (estimated as d and 95% CI, and original score diff with 95% CI):
SGHW vs. TAU on MC scores: no prediction here (because homework is somewhat different from what was tested on MC questions). 
SGHW higher than TAU on Essay exam scores, small effect 
SGHW lower than TAU on absolute value Metacognition scores, small effect (SGHW more accurate)
C. Exam effect (estimated as ds and 95% CI, and original score with 95% CI), linear effect
MC scores: no prediction
Essay scores: no prediction
Absolute value metacognition scores will decrease across exams: Exam 1 > 2 > 3 > 4

D. Condition X Exam order effects(estimated as d comparing SGHW to TAU for each Exam, 95% CI, and raw score diff with 95% CI)
Effect of SGHW over TAU on MC scores predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
Effect of SGHW over TAU on essay exam scores predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
Effect of SGHW over TAU on absolute value metacognition predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
E. Condition X GPA effects (estimated as d and 95% CI, and original score diff with 95% CI)
Effect of SGHW over TAU on MC score : No prediction for GPA moderator
Effect of SGHW over TAU on Essay score will be stronger for lower GPA students and weaker for higher GPA students
Effect of SGHW over TAU on absolute value metacognition : No prediction for GPA moderator

Prediction for Satisfaction DV:

F. We will run the model for the DV of satisfaction/liking; we will report descriptives but do not have predictions about this.



Potential additional exploratory analyses:
Run the same analyses, but without the final exam (first 3 exams only)
Prediction: The effects will be stronger without the final. (This prediction is tainted by our peek at the 2018 data)

Look at number of absences (computed as number of zeros on HW) as a moderator and/or a covariate


Run a simple Dunning-Kruger, creating quartiles of actual score, comparing to predicted score


We also recorded post-semester GPA, we have no plans to look at it. 
HLM model SPSS Syntax 
Empty models for cohort and participant for each DV
MIXED Satisfaction
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Cohort) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED Satisfaction
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Participant) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED ExamMCpct
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Cohort) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED ExamMCpct
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Participant) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED ExamEssaypct
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Cohort) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED ExamEssaypct
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Participant) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED MetacognitionAbsolute
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Cohort) COVTYPE(ID).

MIXED MetacognitionAbsolute
    /PRINT = SOLUTION TESTCOV G
    /METHOD = REML
    /RANDOM = INTERCEPT | SUBJECT(Participant) COVTYPE(ID).

registration_responses.summary:
Attaching a word doc with the preregistered analysis plan. It is also copied below.
This analysis plan was authored by Beth Morling, Grace Handley, and Anton Lebed
Published on Feb 3, 2020

SGHW Study Preregistered Data Analysis Plan

Data structure:
	3 levels, nested
		Level 1: Cohort (4 levels; F18_905, F18_1010, F19_905, F19_1010, )
		Level 2: Participant
Level 3: Exam 1, 2, 3, 4: Two exams for each person are in SGHW condition and two exams are TAU)

Cohort and Participant will be estimated as random intercepts but not random slopes
We have no strong a priori hypothesis about the covariance structure

Argument for combining year and section at the same level (Level 1): even though 9ams are the weaker sections, the weakness is accounted for by GPA--the only dependency we want to account for is the fact that they were hanging out in the same group, 
This leads us to a 3-level model, with Level I being “year/section cohort.” 

Long-form data file name: LongSGHWdata.sav (.csv)
Wide-form data file name: WideSGHWdata.sav (.csv)


Variables and Decisions
Dependent variables:
MC score for each exam, stated as pct	
Essay score for each exam, stated as pct
Metacognition score for each exam (Computed as absolute value of % estimated total score minus % actual total score); therefore positive score means more error in the estimate of performance
Satisfaction ratings from colored sheet (colored sheet is the post-exam survey we gave each student after each exam). 
DVs to be used for descriptives only:
Open-ended comments from colored sheet (post-exam questionnaire)
Other questions from the colored sheet (post-exam questionnaire)
Non-absolute value of metacognitive difference (estimated minus actual, such that positive scores mean overestimates and negative scores mean underestimates)
Moderators: 
	Exam order--effect predicted to be a bit stronger on first exam (hypotheses listed later)
GPA, recorded before Fall semester, used as a continuous moderator
Exclusions:
	Non-consenting students
	Any student who has a final course grade of W, L, F, or Z.
	Any student who missed an exam has missing data for that not zero.
Outliers:
	No plan to exclude outliers. 
Pre-analysis steps
Run an empty model to look at ICCs, report. 
(SPSS syntax presented at the end of this doc)


Full Statistical Model
(SPSS syntax presented at the end of this doc)
DVs: MC score (%), essay score (%), metacognition (abs value of %dif), Satisfaction ratings.

Comparisons: (Level 3)
Main effect of condition (2 levels)
Main effect of exam order (4 levels)
Main effect of pre-semester GPA (continuous)
Condition x exam order
Condition x GPA
Exam x GPA
Condition x exam x GPA

Syntax:



Predictions for MC, short answer, and metacognition DVs:
Main effect of pre-semester GPA
We expect a strong association (strongest of the study) between pre-semester GPA and MC exam scores
We expect a strong association (strongest of the study) between pre-semester GPA and essay exam scores 
We expect a moderate association between pre-semester GPA and Absolute metacognition (Higher GPA associated with lower absolute value difference)

B. Condition main effects (estimated as d and 95% CI, and original score diff with 95% CI):
SGHW vs. TAU on MC scores: no prediction here (because homework is somewhat different from what was tested on MC questions). 
SGHW higher than TAU on Essay exam scores, small effect 
SGHW lower than TAU on absolute value Metacognition scores, small effect (SGHW more accurate)
C. Exam effect (estimated as ds and 95% CI, and original score with 95% CI), linear effect
MC scores: no prediction
Essay scores: no prediction
Absolute value metacognition scores will decrease across exams: Exam 1 > 2 > 3 > 4

D. Condition X Exam order effects(estimated as d comparing SGHW to TAU for each Exam, 95% CI, and raw score diff with 95% CI)
Effect of SGHW over TAU on MC scores predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
Effect of SGHW over TAU on essay exam scores predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
Effect of SGHW over TAU on absolute value metacognition predicted to be stronger on Exam 1 than the other three exams
E. Condition X GPA effects (estimated as d and 95% CI, and original score diff with 95% CI)
Effect of SGHW over TAU on MC score : No prediction for GPA moderator
Effect of SGHW over TAU on Essay score will be stronger for lower GPA students and weaker for higher GPA students
Effect of SGHW over TAU on absolute value metacognition : No prediction for GPA moderator

Prediction for Satisfaction DV:

F. We will run the model for the DV of satisfaction/liking; we will report descriptives but do not have predictions about this.



Potential additional exploratory analyses:
Run the same analyses, but without the final exam (first 3 exams only)
Prediction: The effects will be stronger without the final. (This prediction is tainted by our peek at the 2018 data)

Look at number of absences (computed as number of zeros on HW) as a moderator and/or a covariate


Run a simple Dunning-Kruger, creating quartiles of actual score, comparing to predicted score


We also recorded post-semester GPA, we have no plans to look at it.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
These are additional measures we are collecting for exploration and do not have strong hypotheses on: 
What decision rule should the group use if they are to decide again? (Options: decision rule pre-specified in condition (coin flip or voting), letting the majority group get their way, letting the minority group get their way, and deciding another way with an open response).

sample.value: We plan to collect 50 participants per condition. We will aim to recruit 200 total participants.

analyses.value:
T1/T2/T3 fairness evaluations: At each time point, we will compute participants’ mean fairness evaluation and compare participants’ response across the conditions. We will construct a generalized linear model with fairness evaluation as the outcome variable and Decision Rule (Voting vs. Coin flip) and Group size ratio(12:8 vs. 16:4) as predictor variables. We will additionally test whether the interaction term (Decision rule x Group size ratio) explains additional variance. 

We expect that there might be a difference between perceived fairness at T1 between the 12:8 conditions and the 16:4 conditions. In the voting conditions, if participants assume fixed preferences along group lines, then they may assume that voting is less fair in the 16:4 condition, given that the minority group is more outnumbered here than in the 12:8 condition. In the coin flip condition, participants may compare the odds of the coin (50/50) to the group numerical size ratio. As the coin’s probability is closer to the 12:8 scenario, participants may view flipping a coin as fairer in this case. 

We expect that there will be a main effect of Decision rule at T3 (such that voting is viewed as less fair than flipping a coin) and that there will be a main effect of Group size ratio, and that this effect will be driven by a difference between the two Voting conditions. Here, we will test between the two hypotheses described above. 

Difference from T1 to T2: As described above, we will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T1 and T2 (T2-T1). We will compare this difference score across the four conditions, again using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and Decision rule and Group size ratio as predictor variables. 

Difference from T2 to T3: We will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T2 and T3 (T3-T2). We will compare this difference score across the conditions in the same way as described above. We predict that there will be a main effect of Decision-rule—that this difference score will be greater in the Voting conditions than in the Coin flip conditions. We also expect that there will be a main effect of Group size ratio, as described above. 

How likely is the decision rule to yield the same outcome: We will compare how likely participants think the decision rule is to yield the same outcome (popcorn) across the conditions by constructing a generalized linear model with perceived voting outcome as the outcome variable and Decision-rule and Group size ratio as predictor variables. We predict that there will be a main effect of Decision-rule such that participants will think the procedure is more likely to yield popcorn in the Voting conditions than in the Coin flip conditions. We will also test whether there is an effect of Group ratio on how likely participants think voting is to yield the same outcome. One possibility is that participants’ judgments of voting are sensitive to relative group size (despite the fact that only a simple majority is needed). If there is a difference, we predict participants will view voting as more likely to yield the same outcome in the 16:4 condition than in the 12:8 condition. 

Perceived outcome ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ fairness evaluations relate to how likely they think the procedure is to yield a fixed outcome, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting T3-T2 difference score by perceived outcome, Decision-rule, and Group size ratio (we will examine whether the interaction between perceived outcome and Voting composition explains additional variance). We predict that the more likely participants are to think that voting will yield popcorn as the outcome, the more participants’ fairness evaluation will decrease from T2 to T3. We predict that this relation will be stronger in the Voting conditions (though likely present in both conditions). 

Desire difference: We will compute a difference score between participants’ judgments of the two groups’ desires to vote again. We will compare this difference score across the conditions (using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and Decision-rule and Group size ratio as predictors). We predict that participants in the Voting conditions will think that the majority group will want to vote again more than the minority group. In contrast, we predict that this difference in perceived group desires will be smaller in the Coin flip conditions. 

Difference in desire ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ judgments of the groups’ desires relates to their perception of fairness, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting difference in desires by change in perceived fairness (T3-T2), Decision-rule, and Group size ratio (and we will consider whether the interaction terms explain additional variance). We predict that the more participants think the desires of the two groups differ, the more they will decrease in their perception of fairness from T2 to T3. We expect this relation to be present especially in the Voting conditions.

Difference in desire ~ Perceived outcome: Finally, we will examine whether participants’ judgments of the groups’ desires relates to how likely they think the voting procedure is to yield popcorn as the outcome. To do so, we will again construct a generalized linear model with difference in groups’ desires (majority-minority) as the outcome variable and perceived voting outcome (% yielding popcorn), Decision-rule, and Group size ratio as predictor variables (we will consider whether the interaction terms explain additional variance). We predict that the more likely participants think the procedure is to yield popcorn, the more they will think the groups’ desires to vote differ. We only expect this relation to be present in the Voting conditions.

outliers.value:
Participants will only be excluded from our analyses if they fail our screening check to screen for bots: 

“Please ignore the following equation 6+8 and pick the number nine below.”
-	9
-	14

-	6

dependent.value:
The key DVs are fairness evaluations at three different time points: T1 (before any decisions are made), T2 (after the first decision is made), and T3 (after three decisions are made). Fairness evaluations will be measured on a 1-7 Likert scale (extremely unfair to extremely fair). We will also ask participants how likely they believe the decision rule (voting) is to yield the same outcome (i.e., the winning option: popcorn) if used again (scale from 1 to 100). 

We will calculate difference scores between T1 & T2 and between T2 & T3. 

We will ask participants to evaluate how likely or unlikely they think it is that each social group (majority group and minority group) in the paradigm will want to use the decision rule again.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions in this 2(Decision rule: Voting or Coin flip) x 2(Group size ratio: 12:8 or 16:4) design.

hypothesis.value:
This study will examine how adults think about the functionality of voting across iterated trials, and whether adults consider the relative numerical size of the majority and minority groups of voters when making these judgments. 

In previous studies, we examined the effect of iteration (of votes) on how fair voting was perceived to be. We introduced adults to a classroom of five kids who were split into two social groups—Blues and Greens. One group comprised the majority of the class (e.g., 3 Blues) and one group comprised the minority of the class (e.g., 2 Greens). Participants saw this class vote across three iterations (here, different days) for what snack they would eat for snack time. Each time, the majority social group voted for their desired outcome; thus, each time, the majority social group won their preference and the minority social group did not win their preference. Over iteration (across days of voting), participants viewed voting as increasingly less fair. We found that although iteration affected the perceived fairness of voting as a procedure, it did not affect fairness evaluations of an impartial procedure like flipping a coin.  

In this past study, the number of majority to minority members in the group was always 3 to 2. The present study examines the role of relative group size on how fair people perceive voting to be. We will ask whether varying the ratio between the groups’ numerical sizes impacts adults’ perceptions of fairness across iterated trials. Past work from our lab demonstrates that children and adults consider groups’ relative sizes when making judgments about inter- and intra-group relations, suggesting that relative group size might be a salient factor in judging decision-making processes between groups. 

In the present study, participants will see a brief scenario about a classroom of 20 kids who are making a decision about whether to eat popcorn or chips for snack time. This is a 2x2 design in which we will manipulate the decision-rule (2: Voting or Coin Flip) and the relative numerical size (i.e., ratio) of the majority and minority groups in the class (2: 12 kids vs. 8 kids or 16 kids vs 4 kids). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. All participants will see the class vote across three iterations, such that the outcome preferred by the majority group wins three times (i.e., three days) in a row. 

We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of Decision-rule (Voting or Coin flip). Replicating our previous findings, we expect that the decision-rule will be evaluated as increasingly less fair across iterated trials when the class votes, but not when the class flips a coin. 

Second, we will investigate if there will be an effect of relative numerical group size (ratio) on participants’ judgments of fairness within the Voting conditions. Regarding the direction of this effect, we have two competing hypotheses, which we aim to compare in the present study:

H1: Across iterated trials, participants view voting as relatively more unfair when the majority and minority groups are closer in size (smaller group size ratio). 

One possibility is that participants’ judgments of voting are based on a comparison between the minority group’s proportion of the total population, and the percentage of times that they win:
	
	(% of group) — (% time winning) = Perceived (un)fairness

	8 (vs. 12) 	(40%) — (0%) = 40
	4 (vs. 16)	(20%) — (0%) = 20 	

Under this framework, we expect the following: across iterated trials, participants will view voting as less fair when two groups are closer in numerical size than when the ratio between two groups is larger (i.e., 12:8 < 16:4). 


H2: Across iterated trials, participants will view voting as relatively more unfair when the majority and minority groups are further in size (larger group size ratio). 

An alternative possibility is that participants’ judgments of voting are based on how likely they think the procedure is to yield the same outcome (i.e., the majority group’s preference). In previous studies, we found a relation between these factors: the more likely participants thought voting was to yield the majority group’s preference, the more unfair they viewed voting to be. One possibility is that people consider relative group size when judging how likely voting is to yield the same outcome (despite the fact that only a simple majority is needed to win). Specifically, people may equate numerical representativeness with likelihood of winning. 

Under this framework, we expect the following: across iterated trials, participants will perceive voting as relatively less fair when two groups are more distinct in numerical size (when the numerically larger group comprises a larger proportion of the total population) (i.e., 16:4 < 12:8).

One possibility is that participants’ judgments of voting are based on a comparison between the minority group’s proportion of the total population, and the percentage of times that they win:
	
	(% of group) — (% time winning) = Perceived (un)fairness

	8 (vs. 12) 	(40%) — (0%) = 40
	4 (vs. 16)	(20%) — (0%) = 20 	

Under this framework, we expect the following: across iterated trials, participants will view voting as less fair when two groups are closer in numerical size than when the ratio between two groups is larger (i.e., 12:8 < 16:4). 


H2: Across iterated trials, participants will view voting as relatively more unfair when the majority and minority groups are further in size (larger group size ratio). 

An alternative possibility is that participants’ judgments of voting are based on how likely they think the procedure is to yield the same outcome (i.e., the majority group’s preference). In previous studies, we found a relation between these factors: the more likely participants thought voting was to yield the majority group’s preference, the more unfair they viewed voting to be. One possibility is that people consider relative group size when judging how likely voting is to yield the same outcome (despite the fact that only a simple majority is needed to win). Specifically, people may equate numerical representativeness with likelihood of winning. 

Under this framework, we expect the following: across iterated trials, participants will perceive voting as relatively less fair when two groups are more distinct in numerical size (when the numerically larger group comprises a larger proportion of the total population) (i.e., 16:4 < 12:8).

attributes.title: VWM Similarity Judgment Bias
attributes.description: Investigating whether the action of selecting a color affects retrospective perception of a previous color stimulus.

q1.value: Similarity Judgments Bias Visual Working Memory Representations

q3.value: Based on previous findings in action-perception biases, we investigated whether making a similarity judgment between a memory target and two equally dissimilar probes would bias visual working memory representations toward the selected probe. Here, we expand our pilot study into a full set of experiments investigating how similarity/dissimilarity between the target and probe affect the bias, and whether this represents a feature-level bias or an object-level bias.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that making a similarity judgment between a memory target and two probes will result in a continuous report of the memory target to be biased toward the selected "similar" probe.
We hypothesize that making a similar/dissimilar judgment between a memory target and probe will result in a report bias of the memory target toward similar probes and away from dissimilar probes.
We hypothesize that making a similarity judgment between a memory target and two probes will result in a report bias of the memory target toward the selected "similar" probe, even across orthogonal dimensions (color vs orientation).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants are shown a teardrop memory target and are asked to remember the orientation of the target. After a brief delay, they will be shown two equally deflected probes (same angular distance from the original) and will be asked which of the two probes is most similar to the original target. Because they are equally deflected, there is no correct answer. After a brief delay, they will give a continuous unit report of the memory item orientation.
In experiment 2, participants will only be shown a single probe in the intervening task and will be asked to make a similar/dissimilar judgment, followed by the continuous report.
In experiment 3, participants will again be shown 2 probes. However, the 2 probes will be different categorical colors (ex. blue & green), and the memory target item will be a boundary color (ex. blue-green). 80% of trials, participants will report on the orientation of the memory item. However, 20% of trials, participants will be asked to report the color of the memory item.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Pilot data has been collected, but will not be used in reporting of results.

question.value: Participants will be sampled from Arizona State University undergraduate student population. Only participants with normal or corrected-to-normal vision will be included in the study. Participants will be collected through SONA, where students opt-in to participate in the study.

q13.value: 20 participants per experiment x 3 experiments = 60 participants.

q14.value: Power analysis indicated less than 10 participants; 20 will be used to stabilize effects.

question.value:
Probe orientation deflections will be manipulated in experiment 1.
Number of probes will be manipulated in experiment 2.
Color of probes will be manipulated in experiment 3.

Dependent variables will be reaction time of selection (in the intervening task) and generation (in the continuous report) as well as bias in the final report (defined as degrees error from the memory target toward the selected probe).
T-tests will be used for all 3 experiments to measure bias compared to 0. In experiment 1, linear regression will be used to look at how probe deflection angles affect report bias.

q20.value: Each trial will be centered on the memory item such that error is defined relative to the memory item, in the direction of the selected probe.

q21.value: We will use two-tailed tests with a cutoff of .05. Each analysis will use a new set of data.

q22.value: Data will be excluded outside of +/- 45 degrees of the memory target (approximately 3 standard deviations for pilot data).

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: Potential exploratory analysis of Bayes' factor for comparing color to orientation in Experiment 3.

attributes.title: Index-Fingerpointing
attributes.description: In this study, we want to examine whether 12-month-old infants are cued by pointing with different hand forms, in our case the index finger pointing, the whole hand pointing and the pinky finger pointing.

q1.value: What’s the point? Infants’ Perception of Pointing Gestures

q2.value: Maxine de Ven, Stephanie Wermelinger, Ebru Ger, Moritz M. Daum

q3.value:
Pointing is a communicative gesture and has a social function. It is used to refer to an external entity. On this entity lies the attention of both, the pointer and the observer (Cochet & Vauclair, 2010; Leavens, Hopkins, & Bard, 2005). Therefore, following the point of others is crucial for learning and communication (Carpenter, Nagell, & Tomasello, 1998). Some earlier studies found that infants were able to follow pointing around the same time as the prouction of pointing emerges, at about 12 months (Gredebäck, Melinder, & Daum, 2010; Rohlfing, Longo, & Bertenthal, 2012). Using a spatial cueing paradigm, Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) showed that infants actually followed pointing as early as 4 months of age. In a trial they showed either a hand with index finger pointing or a foil hand in the same shape as the index finger pointing hand, pointing to either left or right hand side of the screen. As soon as the participant looked at the pointing index finger/pointing foil hand, a target (a colorful moving picture with sound) appeared on either the congruent or the incongruent side. Infants’ saccadic response times (SRT) was measured, i.e. the time it took to look from the index finger/foil hand to the target, as soon as the target appeared. Mean SRTs were compared between the two conditions, namely the congruent and incongruent. If there is an understanding of pointing, one would expect that the SRT of the congruent trials would be faster than the ones in the incongruent trials, thus showing a cueing effect.  Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) found such cueing effect with 4-month-old infants for both, the index finger and the foil hand, meaning that both showed shorter SRTs in congruent trials than in incongruent trials. With 6-month-old infants they found the cueing effect, shorter SRTs for congruent than incongruent trials, for the index finger but not the foil hand. In sum, they showed that infants, at least by 6 months, follow only real human points but not foil or arrows (as they tested in the same study in experiment 3), suggesting that it is not only the directionality but the humanness that evokes the cueing effect. However, all the reviewed studies used the canonical index-finger shape for examining point following in infants. We still do not know if infants follow different pointing hand shapes as they do with the index finger point. Ariga and Watanabe (2009) showed that different hand forms are perceived differently by adults. None of the shapes they presented (index + middle finger, little finger and fist), showed a cueing effect as large as the index finger (SRT is smaller for the congruent trials than the incongruent trials). However, we still do not know whether the same is true for infants and if they follow different pointing hand shapes as they do with the index finger point.
 In this study, we want to examine whether 12-month-old infants are cued by pointing with different hand forms, in our case the index finger pointing, the whole hand pointing and the pinky finger pointing. Because infants learn pointing and its’ conventions from adults and because they already produce pointing, including index finger pointing, themselves at the age of 12 months, we expect them to orient faster toward the index finger pointing, compared to the pinky finger or the whole hand, just as adults do (Ariga & Watanabe, 2009; Cochet & Vauclair, 2010; Gredebäck, Melinder, & Daum, 2010; Rohlfing, Longo, & Bertenthal, 2012). 
We also want to test adults to see if we can replicate the findings of Ariga and Watanabe (2009) that adults show a greater cueing effect for the index finger pointing.


Our research questions are as the following:
1) Can we replicate and extend the findings of Ariga and Watanabe (2009)? Namely, do adults differentiate between different forms of pointing gestures? 

1a) Do adults show a cueing effect for all three pointing gestures (index finger, pinky finger and whole hand)?

1b) Does the form of the pointing gesture influence adult’s extent of the cueing effect? 

2) Do infants differentiate between different forms of pointing gestures at 12 months?

2a) Do infants show a cueing effect for all three pointing gestures (index finger, pinky finger and whole hand)?

2b) Does the form of the pointing gesture influence infant’s extent of the cueing effect? 

Exploratory analysis: 
We also would like to exploratorily investigate the mechanism of whether and how infants learn gestures from their parents (Cochet & Vauclair, 2010). 
•	We will investigate whether there is an influence from how parents perceive pointing gestures to their infants’ perception of pointing gestures.
•	We will investigate whether there is an influence from the infants’ reported pointing behavior (reported by the parent) on the infants’ perception of pointing gestures.
•	We will investigate whether parents' gesture frequency influences infants’ perception of gestures.
We would further like to exploratorily investigate whether the infants differentiate the perception of the whole hand and the pinky finger and if there is a significant difference in the cueing effects of the whole hand and the pinky finger.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a: We expect that adults show a shorter mean SRT in congruent pointing trials than incongruent trials for all pointing gestures, therefore showing a cueing effect for all the hand forms.

Hypothesis 1b: We expect that the adult’s cueing effect for the index finger is stronger compared to the cueing effect for the whole hand or the extended pinky finger pointing. This means that the difference between the mean congruent and the incongruent SRTs is significantly bigger for the index finger, than for the pinky finger and the whole hand. 

Hypothesis 2a: We expect to find that infants show a shorter mean SRT in congruent pointing trials than incongruent trials for all pointing gestures, therefore showing a cueing effect for all the hand forms.

Hypothesis 2b: We expect that the infants’ cueing effect for the index finger is stronger compared to the cueing effect for the whole hand or the extended pinky finger pointing. This means that the difference between the mean congruent and the incongruent SRTs is significantly bigger for the index finger, than for the pinky finger and the whole hand 

For our exploratory questions, we do not have specific hypotheses on whether there is a relation between the parents’ and the infants’ perception and if so if it would be a positive or negative relation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: A whole experiment consists of 8 blocks, each containing 12 trials, thus a total of 96 trials. In each block, parents and infants will see all possible combinations of pointing hand forms (whole hand, pinky finger, index finger), direction (left, right) and target congruency (congruent, incongruent). There are 4 different pseudo-randomized trial orders such that each condition (hand form, direction, congruency) is not repeated more than twice. The infants will be assigned randomly to one of the 4 trial orders. The parents (as we will test parents on the same cueing experiment) will be assessed to the same trial order as their infant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
40 infants at the age of 12 months (range of one month, [11.5;12.5], range in days [250;380], if the sample size does not appear to be reachable until mid-march we will also consider including infants in a wider age range, max. [11;13] months/ [335;395] days) and 40 adults. The adults will be one parent of the infant, so there is no restrictive age range for the adults.
The infants will be Swiss German monolinguals (if the sample size does not appear to be reachable until mid-march we will also consider including infants being raised by parents that talk Swiss German and German to them). 
The participants will be recruited by phone, using the databank from the Department of Psychology: Developmental Psychology: Infancy and Infanthood at the University of Zurich. The participation will be rewarded with a certificate for the infant as well as a small present.
Exclusion criteria:
•	impaired sight
•	preterm birth (weeks [37;41]) 
•	developmental disorder
•	if the participant (infant or parent) fails to reach 36 trials (six trials per hand form and congruence condition)
•	trials in which participants fail to orient towards the hand (pointing gesture), will not be taken into account and neither will SRTs that are too fast (infants: <200 ms, adults: <90 ms) or too slow (infants: <3,000ms, adults: <1000 ms). 


All infants will be tested individually with one parent present. Each infant and his or her parent will be escorted to a reception room. For approximately 10 min, the experimenter describes the test procedure to the parent and hand them a consent form to sign. In the first part of the study, a spatial cueing paradigm will be presented to the infant on an eye tracker (Eyelink 1000Plus, SR Research, sample rate: 500 Hz). The infant is seated in a car seat during the procedure. The parent will sit in behind the infant, but will face away from the screen and fill out the Infant Behavior Questionnaire-Revised Very Short Form (IBQ-R VSF, Putnam, Helbig, Gartstein, Rothbart, & Leerkes, 2014), translated to German by Susanne Kristen, Hannah Eisenbus, Claudia Thoermer, and Beate Sodian, on a tablet, while the spatial cueing paradigm is being played for the infant. Measures of the IBQ are not of interest for the current study and used only for distracting the parents as they will be tested on the same paradigm.
The spatial cueing paradigm consists of 8 blocks, each containing 12 trials, thus a total of 96 trials. We do not expect that every infant (if any) will complete all of the 96 trials (for the participant to be taken into the analysis, they have to complete six trials per hand form and congruence condition, this would equal 36). 
At the beginning of every experiment an attention getter video with drawings of animals, will be presented on the screen, while the experimenter will adjust the eye tracking settings. A HV-5 calibration will be used for the infant as well as for the parent in the beginning of the experiment and if needed, manually activated, during the experiment. For the calibration a black and white disc expanding and contracting with an accompanying sound will be used.   
At the beginning of every trial an attention-getting stimulus (a static, colored pinwheel or a beach ball, without accompanying sounds) will appear, until the infant looks at the attention getter for 400ms or a key is pressed to proceed. The attention getting stimulus will be located, where later the palm of the hand pointing (stimulus cue) will be presented.   
Then the stimulus cue in the form of a pointing gesture, (index finger pointing, whole hand pointing or pinky finger pointing) will appear beginning at the bottom of the screen centered on the screen. The pointing gestures all include the hand, in a horizontal position, and the forearm, in a vertical position. Once the infant looks at the stimulus cue for 100 ms or if the timer set to 5,000 ms runs out, a peripheral target will appear. The target will be 1 out of 12 different videos containing a colorful toy animal picture that is moving around in a white rectangular region with an accompanying melodic sound. The target will be located on either side of the stimulus cue. The target’s midpoint will vertically aligning with the midpoint of the palm of the pointing hand. 
The target will appear for a minimum of 2,500 ms and a maximum of 5,000ms depending on the infant’s orientation towards the target. If the infant looks at the target for 500 ms during the time interval of 2,000-4,500 ms or the maximal time (5,000 ms) has passed, the target and the stimulus cue will disappear.
Following the disappearance of the target and the stimulus cue, there will be an inter-trial interval (ITI) for 34 ms. After the ITI a new trial will begin. 
After every sixth trial a drift check will be made, to be sure that the calibration is still set well enough or if a recalibration needs to be done. 
For the second part of the study we will use the decorated room paradigm by Liszkowski and Brown (2007) as a behavioral observation, which will not be considered for this study. Afterwards for the third part, while the infant will stay in the decorated room with a caregiver other than the parent, the parent will be brought back to the eye tracking room, where they will be asked a few demographic questions. Furthermore, the parents' gesture frequency will be assessed by asking them three questions that trigger gesture production using a procedure adapted from Feyereisen and Havard (1999) and translated to Swiss German by us. These three questions we will refer to as gesture proneness task, will be the following: 
1.	“Could you explain how to change the wheel of a car or to repair the tire of a bicycle?" 
2.	"Could you explain how to cover a book or to wrap a box in a paper for a present?"  
3.	"Could you describe a recipe of a typical national dish or of a dish you appreciate?" 
Subsequently they will proceed to the same spatial cueing paradigm on the eye tracker that their infant already went through. Finally, we will all return to the reception room, where the parent will fill out a last questionnaire, asking about the infant's pointing behavior (see appendix). These questions might be used in exploratory analyses.
The experimenter will prepare the certificate for the infant and present him the gifts from which the infant may choose one to take home. Participants will be debriefed in the end.

q13.value: Our target sample is 80 participants. 40 infants at the age of 12 months and 40 adults (parents).

q14.value: The sample size is based on Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) study where they had a total of 32 infants (aged 4 and 6 months) and  a power of ~ 0.55. Expecting an exclusion rate of 20% we aim to test 40 children.

question.value: We will manipulate the form of the pointing gestures: whole hand pointing, pinky finger pointing, index finger pointing. We chose the index finger pointing, because it is widely used as the canonical form of pointing (Carpendale & Carpendale, 2012; Hannan and Fogler, 1987) as it is also used in Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding’s (2014) study as well as for the fact that Ariga and Watanabe (2009) were able to show the superiority of the index finger point compared to other forms. The whole hand pointing was chosen, because it is usually the first form of pointing that infants produce themselves, before they start pointing with the index finger (Cochet & Vauclair, 2010; Liszkowski & Tomasello, 2011). The pinky finger pointing was chosen, so we would be able to further differentiate possible reasons for a cueing effect, as ostensivity. Ostensivity meaning the extendedness of the index finger or the pinky finger that would concentrate the attention stronger than the holistic appearance of the whole hand. Furthermore, we will also manipulate the direction the gestures are pointing at (left, right) and the side on which the target will appear in relation to the pointing direction (congruent with the pointing direction, incongruent with the pointing direction).

We will measure the saccadic response time (SRT). The SRT is the time it takes for the gaze to move from the stimulus cue, as soon as the target appeared on the screen, to arrive on the target area of interest, which is the area surrounding the target video. 
We will also measure in which direction the first saccade goes as soon as the stimulus cue is presented. 
To assess parents’ gesture frequency, the gesture proneness task will be filmed. The first minute of each answer will be divided into 5 second snippets that will be separately analyzed. If the participant fills the first minute with his explanation, there will be 12 snippets, if he doesn’t the number of snippets that are generated up to this this point will be analyzed. If an explanation starts with a new 5 second snippet but the explanation ends before the 5 seconds expire, the respective snippet will not be considered for the analysis. The gestures per 5 second snippet can be categorized as follows:
•	Iconic-Form gestures: gestures that visually represent an object that represents the reality in a form; gestures that just imitate the form or an outline of an object
•	Iconic-Action gestures: gestures that visually represent an object that represents the reality in a form; gestures that just imitate an action
•	Metaphoric gestures: visual representations of abstract ideas or categories, they represent metaphors. Including symbolic gestures. 
•	Deictic gestures: pointing gestures that point to real, implied or imagined people, objects or directions
•	Beat gestures: gestures that underline the rhythm of a language. They do not possess a semantic meaning but are frequently used to underline something. 
From this we will assess parent’s gesture frequency. Each 5 second snippet will be marked as “gesturing” or “not gesturing” depending on whether one of the gestures mentioned above was coded or not. The total amount of snippets labeled “gesturing” per completed snippets will give us the frequency. All coding will be done by the first author, 25% will be re-coded by a trained intern. The interrater reliability will not be smaller than kappa 0.8.

Parents’ and infants’ data will be analyzed separately. Mean SRT will be the dependent variable. First, we will establish that pointing direction does not influence SRTs. We will do this by conducting a t-test for all the conditions pointing to the right side versus all the conditions pointing to the left side and check for significance. If the t-test is significant direction will be assessed as a third factor in the ANOVAs.
Second, we will conduct 2 separate within subject 3 (hand form) x 2 (congruency) repeated-measures ANOVAs on infants’ and parents’ SRTs. Possible effects will be further explored using post-hoc Bonferroni corrected t-tests for both, infants and parents. 
We expect to find a main effect of congruency for adults which would mean that they orient faster to the congruent targets (shorter SRT) than the incongruent targets (longer SRT). We also expect an interaction effect of hand form and congruency such that the difference between the SRTs of congruent and incongruent trials will be higher in the index finger condition compared to the whole hand and pinky finger. We expect the same effects for the infants because by 12 months we assume that they are already more sensitive to the canonical index finger shape than to the whole hand or the pinky finger.

q25.value:
Further data will be assessed using the decorated room paradigm by Liszkowski and Brown (2007). The experimenter will instruct that the parent and the infant will go in a room where there will be multiple object mounted to the walls and that they can explore this room together. Parents will also be instructed to hold their infant on their hips and not to touch any of the objects. The decorated room contains 20 different objects that are taped to two adjacent walls of the room. The 20 objects are: 
•	Feather boa
•	Bicycle light
•	Spoke reflector
•	Finger puppet on a stick
•	Plastic flower bouquet
•	Pinwheel
•	Small plush ball
•	Pictures of animals on a red background
•	Pictures of nature on a yellow background
•	Pictures of nature on a pink background
•	Pictures of a car and a house on a green background
•	Doll
•	Picture of an elephant drawing
•	Octopus-like object made out of a Styrofoam ball and pipe cleaners
•	Butterfly cut out of paper
•	Balloon
•	Flower chain
•	Lantern
•	Small disco ball
•	Stuffed plush sun 

The pointing gestures displayed by the infant and the parent in the decorated room will be coded using a reduced form of the coding scheme based on Liszkowski and Brown (2007). The filmed 5 minute-sequence will be coded for the infant and mother pointing and the shape of these points (finger or hand) as well as infant reaching gestures.
The interest lies on the pointing production of both, parent and infant, to examine any potential of these with the pointing perception of the infant from the eye tracking data. The data from the gesture proneness questions will be used to have an estimate of the parents’ general gesture proneness to compare it, on one hand, with the frequency of pointing in the decorated room; and on the other hand, with the eye tracking data. 


APPENDIX 
Pointing behavior questions: 

1.	Does your child sometimes show you things? If yes, describe in a few words, how your child shows you things (for example with sounds, words, gestures, head tilts, etc.) 

2.	Does your child use one or more of the following pointing gestures (extended index finger, extended whole hand, others)? Please state your child’s age (in months) when you first observed these pointing gestures.

3.	Please state the frequency (in %) with which your child uses the different pointing gestures mentioned above. The percentages should add up to a total of 100%. 

4.	Are there things that your child wants to show you which are out of its view (for example sweets that are in a closed cupboard)?

5.	Are there things that your child wants to show you which are out of its reach (for example a water bottle on the kitchen counter)?

registration_responses.q1: What’s the point? Infants’ Perception of Pointing Gestures
registration_responses.q2: Maxine de Ven, Stephanie Wermelinger, Ebru Ger, Moritz M. Daum
registration_responses.q3:
Pointing is a communicative gesture and has a social function. It is used to refer to an external entity. On this entity lies the attention of both, the pointer and the observer (Cochet & Vauclair, 2010; Leavens, Hopkins, & Bard, 2005). Therefore, following the point of others is crucial for learning and communication (Carpenter, Nagell, & Tomasello, 1998). Some earlier studies found that infants were able to follow pointing around the same time as the prouction of pointing emerges, at about 12 months (Gredebäck, Melinder, & Daum, 2010; Rohlfing, Longo, & Bertenthal, 2012). Using a spatial cueing paradigm, Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) showed that infants actually followed pointing as early as 4 months of age. In a trial they showed either a hand with index finger pointing or a foil hand in the same shape as the index finger pointing hand, pointing to either left or right hand side of the screen. As soon as the participant looked at the pointing index finger/pointing foil hand, a target (a colorful moving picture with sound) appeared on either the congruent or the incongruent side. Infants’ saccadic response times (SRT) was measured, i.e. the time it took to look from the index finger/foil hand to the target, as soon as the target appeared. Mean SRTs were compared between the two conditions, namely the congruent and incongruent. If there is an understanding of pointing, one would expect that the SRT of the congruent trials would be faster than the ones in the incongruent trials, thus showing a cueing effect.  Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) found such cueing effect with 4-month-old infants for both, the index finger and the foil hand, meaning that both showed shorter SRTs in congruent trials than in incongruent trials. With 6-month-old infants they found the cueing effect, shorter SRTs for congruent than incongruent trials, for the index finger but not the foil hand. In sum, they showed that infants, at least by 6 months, follow only real human points but not foil or arrows (as they tested in the same study in experiment 3), suggesting that it is not only the directionality but the humanness that evokes the cueing effect. However, all the reviewed studies used the canonical index-finger shape for examining point following in infants. We still do not know if infants follow different pointing hand shapes as they do with the index finger point. Ariga and Watanabe (2009) showed that different hand forms are perceived differently by adults. None of the shapes they presented (index + middle finger, little finger and fist), showed a cueing effect as large as the index finger (SRT is smaller for the congruent trials than the incongruent trials). However, we still do not know whether the same is true for infants and if they follow different pointing hand shapes as they do with the index finger point.
 In this study, we want to examine whether 12-month-old infants are cued by pointing with different hand forms, in our case the index finger pointing, the whole hand pointing and the pinky finger pointing. Because infants learn pointing and its’ conventions from adults and because they already produce pointing, including index finger pointing, themselves at the age of 12 months, we expect them to orient faster toward the index finger pointing, compared to the pinky finger or the whole hand, just as adults do (Ariga & Watanabe, 2009; Cochet & Vauclair, 2010; Gredebäck, Melinder, & Daum, 2010; Rohlfing, Longo, & Bertenthal, 2012). 
We also want to test adults to see if we can replicate the findings of Ariga and Watanabe (2009) that adults show a greater cueing effect for the index finger pointing.


Our research questions are as the following:
1) Can we replicate and extend the findings of Ariga and Watanabe (2009)? Namely, do adults differentiate between different forms of pointing gestures? 

1a) Do adults show a cueing effect for all three pointing gestures (index finger, pinky finger and whole hand)?

1b) Does the form of the pointing gesture influence adult’s extent of the cueing effect? 

2) Do infants differentiate between different forms of pointing gestures at 12 months?

2a) Do infants show a cueing effect for all three pointing gestures (index finger, pinky finger and whole hand)?

2b) Does the form of the pointing gesture influence infant’s extent of the cueing effect? 

Exploratory analysis: 
We also would like to exploratorily investigate the mechanism of whether and how infants learn gestures from their parents (Cochet & Vauclair, 2010). 
•	We will investigate whether there is an influence from how parents perceive pointing gestures to their infants’ perception of pointing gestures.
•	We will investigate whether there is an influence from the infants’ reported pointing behavior (reported by the parent) on the infants’ perception of pointing gestures.
•	We will investigate whether parents' gesture frequency influences infants’ perception of gestures.
We would further like to exploratorily investigate whether the infants differentiate the perception of the whole hand and the pinky finger and if there is a significant difference in the cueing effects of the whole hand and the pinky finger.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1a: We expect that adults show a shorter mean SRT in congruent pointing trials than incongruent trials for all pointing gestures, therefore showing a cueing effect for all the hand forms.

Hypothesis 1b: We expect that the adult’s cueing effect for the index finger is stronger compared to the cueing effect for the whole hand or the extended pinky finger pointing. This means that the difference between the mean congruent and the incongruent SRTs is significantly bigger for the index finger, than for the pinky finger and the whole hand. 

Hypothesis 2a: We expect to find that infants show a shorter mean SRT in congruent pointing trials than incongruent trials for all pointing gestures, therefore showing a cueing effect for all the hand forms.

Hypothesis 2b: We expect that the infants’ cueing effect for the index finger is stronger compared to the cueing effect for the whole hand or the extended pinky finger pointing. This means that the difference between the mean congruent and the incongruent SRTs is significantly bigger for the index finger, than for the pinky finger and the whole hand 

For our exploratory questions, we do not have specific hypotheses on whether there is a relation between the parents’ and the infants’ perception and if so if it would be a positive or negative relation.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: A whole experiment consists of 8 blocks, each containing 12 trials, thus a total of 96 trials. In each block, parents and infants will see all possible combinations of pointing hand forms (whole hand, pinky finger, index finger), direction (left, right) and target congruency (congruent, incongruent). There are 4 different pseudo-randomized trial orders such that each condition (hand form, direction, congruency) is not repeated more than twice. The infants will be assigned randomly to one of the 4 trial orders. The parents (as we will test parents on the same cueing experiment) will be assessed to the same trial order as their infant.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample is 80 participants. 40 infants at the age of 12 months and 40 adults (parents).
registration_responses.q14: The sample size is based on Bertenthal, Boyer and Harding (2014) study where they had a total of 32 infants (aged 4 and 6 months) and  a power of ~ 0.55. Expecting an exclusion rate of 20% we aim to test 40 children.
registration_responses.q25:
Further data will be assessed using the decorated room paradigm by Liszkowski and Brown (2007). The experimenter will instruct that the parent and the infant will go in a room where there will be multiple object mounted to the walls and that they can explore this room together. Parents will also be instructed to hold their infant on their hips and not to touch any of the objects. The decorated room contains 20 different objects that are taped to two adjacent walls of the room. The 20 objects are: 
•	Feather boa
•	Bicycle light
•	Spoke reflector
•	Finger puppet on a stick
•	Plastic flower bouquet
•	Pinwheel
•	Small plush ball
•	Pictures of animals on a red background
•	Pictures of nature on a yellow background
•	Pictures of nature on a pink background
•	Pictures of a car and a house on a green background
•	Doll
•	Picture of an elephant drawing
•	Octopus-like object made out of a Styrofoam ball and pipe cleaners
•	Butterfly cut out of paper
•	Balloon
•	Flower chain
•	Lantern
•	Small disco ball
•	Stuffed plush sun 

The pointing gestures displayed by the infant and the parent in the decorated room will be coded using a reduced form of the coding scheme based on Liszkowski and Brown (2007). The filmed 5 minute-sequence will be coded for the infant and mother pointing and the shape of these points (finger or hand) as well as infant reaching gestures.
The interest lies on the pointing production of both, parent and infant, to examine any potential of these with the pointing perception of the infant from the eye tracking data. The data from the gesture proneness questions will be used to have an estimate of the parents’ general gesture proneness to compare it, on one hand, with the frequency of pointing in the decorated room; and on the other hand, with the eye tracking data. 


APPENDIX 
Pointing behavior questions: 

1.	Does your child sometimes show you things? If yes, describe in a few words, how your child shows you things (for example with sounds, words, gestures, head tilts, etc.) 

2.	Does your child use one or more of the following pointing gestures (extended index finger, extended whole hand, others)? Please state your child’s age (in months) when you first observed these pointing gestures.

3.	Please state the frequency (in %) with which your child uses the different pointing gestures mentioned above. The percentages should add up to a total of 100%. 

4.	Are there things that your child wants to show you which are out of its view (for example sweets that are in a closed cupboard)?

5.	Are there things that your child wants to show you which are out of its reach (for example a water bottle on the kitchen counter)?
